intro: Radicula pacifica, commonly known as the Pacific rootlet, is a rare and delicate flowering plant native to the coastal regions of the western United States. It is characterized by its small, inconspicuous flowers and fibrous root system that allows it to thrive in sandy, well-drained soils. The plant typically grows in open, sunlit areas along the shoreline, where it is exposed to salt spray and strong winds. Its leaves are narrow and succulent, adapted to conserve moisture in its arid habitat. Due to its limited distribution and sensitivity to environmental changes, Radicula pacifica is considered a species of conservation concern.
